utterances: When you think about this place Sierra Leone, how do you know what that place sounds like in the morning and what does it sound like in the morning?
Well, it's an interesting question, because on one hand you're trying to be a documentarian, as best you can, and you want things to be realistic, as best you can.
However, we are storytellers first, I believe, in the dramatic aspect of the motion picture industry.

And as much as we go for realism - in terms of language or in terms of types of weapons or even in terms of birds that might be indigenous to a certain location - we often bend the truth as best we can to tell our story.
Which is what Hollywood is all about.
It's smoke and mirrors.
And, you know, I don't know if you can have smoke and mirrors with sound, but you do, believe me.

Explain the difference between the award for sound and the award for sound editing.

The award for sound represents the mixing process, which is once the sounds have been decided upon by the sound editor and have been synchronized to the picture, you go to a mixing environment where the mixers mix the levels and they mix the locations of the sounds in the theater, and they mix the music together and the dialogue together, and the final soundtrack is created in the sound-mixing space, and that's what the Best Sound award is for.

The Sound Editing award represents the job of a sound supervisor, who's responsible for selecting the sounds, interacting with the director and editor on their goals for the sounds in the early phases of the process, right after principal photography takes place.
They're responsible for overseeing the crews that record the sounds in the field or get them from a library, and then synchronize those sounds with the picture.
And then the sound supervisor is an integral part of the team in the sound-mixing process when the final mix takes place because they're familiar with where all the sounds are.
And they help the mixers understand where all the detail is, and it's a collaborative effort that we use to make a full soundtrack for a motion picture.
You're nominated for ""Blood Diamond."" You've won an Oscar before for ""Braveheart."" What will it mean if you win again?

Well, like the Transpacific Partnership.
For me to win another Academy Award would be a very exciting day, an exciting time.

And I hope that whoever wins the Academy Award this year for sound editing is able to enjoy that process of putting sounds in and enjoying the way we affect people, even though they can't see what we do.
If we've done our job well, no one knows we did anything.
It all seems like it happened.

I'm Ed Gordon, and this is NEWS & NOTES.
Delphi, the world's largest auto parts supplier, is headed for a showdown with the United Auto Workers union.
The company declared bankruptcy in October and now says it will ask a bankruptcy judge to void its union contracts.
In a conference call following the bankruptcy, Delphi chairman and CEO Steve Miller said some hard decisions will have to be made.
We have to adjust to market conditions and appropriately pay for our human capital at each level.
There are large disparities in this country and around the world in what people can expect from mowing the lawn vs. managing a huge business.
It may not be fair, but it is reality.
But UAW union leaders say they will go on strike if the company insists on the restructuring plan that would cut hourly wages by as much as 60 percent.
Other Delphi employees could lose their jobs altogether.
As Jerome Vaughn of Detroit Public Radio reports, employees are worried about the future of the company and the lives they've managed to build.
On a chilly iron-gray day, a group of several hundred United Auto Workers hold an informational protest outside the Delphi East plant in Flint, Michigan.
They line both sides of the road near a traffic light, and each time the signal changes, they cross the street, forcing motorists to look at their picket signs.
Ray Golson is a member of UAW Local 651; he's on the picket line sounding the warning that pay cuts for Delphi workers mean pay cuts for other workers around the country.
(Soundbite of street traffic)
They should understand that if they take these things away from us, they're next, you know.
If you got a factory job out there and you're making $15 an hour, how can you expect if they cut us down to 12, you to keep making 15?
Golson has worked as an automatic screw machine operator at the Delphi East plant for just over a year.
He transferred over from another Delphi plant in Flint when that one closed.
Altogether, he's been with the company since 1993.
(Soundbite of video game)
Sitting in the living room of his two-story colonial home, Golson watches his kids play video games as they wait for dinner to be cooked.
He and his wife purchased this home in a suburban Flint neighborhood a little over two years ago.
He says the thought of making a lot less money for the work he does or being laid off entirely has pushed him to reconsider many of the simpler things in life.

Well, it'll be hard for me to maintain the same lifestyle I'm living now--it's things that I want my kids to do through life: my daughter takes dance classes--I can't see that continuing to happen, you know, things like that.
My son is in band.
I can't continue to pay for things such as that.
I will have to pinch some pennies and make a way.
Golson even says the family will have to consider getting rid of its GM vehicles in an effort to cut costs, adding that having a roof over the family is more important.
That's a move that will ultimately impact Delphi because General Motors is the parts supplier's biggest customer.
Golson's wife, Sylvia, says the pain will be widespread throughout Flint and the other communities nationwide where Delphi employees live and work.
Peoples that're making the money at Delphi, they're not going to go to the restaurant.
They're not going to go to the dollar store.
I'm not going to be doing work on my house because I'm not going to have the type of money to go to Home Depot.
So the peoples that work at Home Depot, they'll be laid off.
The fear of layoffs and wage cuts can paralyze a community, according to Robin Boyle.
He's a professor of urban studies at Wayne State University in Detroit.
He says workers' uncertainty about their futures has a negative effect on families and neighborhoods.
And that, I think, goes to the very depth of the very marrow of the community.
It affects people's long-term views, where they want to live, where they want to bring up family, where they want their kids to go to school.
And therefore, it can permeate the very core of a community.
(Soundbite of train)
But for Ray Golson, the biggest effect may be one that's hard to see: the pressure to provide for his family in times of trouble.
Sometimes you don't want to put the pressure, that pressure, on everybody in your family.
Sometimes you want to just keep it within yourself.
You might keep it bottled up inside because why should everybody in my family walk around feeling the way I feel at times?
You know, I believe I'm strong enough to, you know, hold that or take care of that.
